title: UEFA talk tough but live in denial and pitiful record combating racism proves it
text:

It is the silence that shames the rulers of European football.

As players across the continent remain unprotected from racist abuse in domestic and international matches, governing body UEFA are saying nothing beyond Tuesday’s soundbite statement, calling on “the football family” to “wage war” on the culprits.

Here, on the sun-kissed banks of Lake Geneva, they continue to live in denial at UEFA’s Swiss headquarters.

Drenched in opulence within the glass-panelled, trophy-lined complex resembling the lair of a Bond villain, there was little appetite to refute the charge that organisation simply doesn’t care enough about racism.

(Image: REUTERS)

(Image: Sportimage)

Image is everything for the governing body dripping with cash.

And the brutal truth is that, for all the controversy surrounding cases just like Monday night’s in Bulgaria, UEFA continue to survive nightmare weeks like the one they’ve just had.

Unsurprisingly, then, that while their staff were pleasant and accommodating no-one was able to tell us why - for all their tough talking - the organisation is still fighting fires across Europe with fans unconcerned by any of their sanctions.

(Image: PA)

(Image: Adam Gerrard / Daily Mirror)

No one able to tell us why UEFA remains so terrified of throwing serial offenders out of their competitions.

No one was able to tell us why Bulgaria remain at risk of just a one-match stadium ban after their fans’ abuse of England’s black players, even though the offence was their third at national level during the Euro2020 qualifiers with another two for their clubs in the Europa League.

Nor was there an explanation as to why UEFA President Aleksander Ceferin, failed to even address this week’s incident in his statement on Tuesday.

Especially when Ceferin, speaking in March after a similar storm, described the racist abuse of Southgate’s players by Montenegro fans as “a disaster”.

(Image: Action Images via Reuters)

Here in the UEFA nerve centre, there was an insistence that 52-year-old lawyer Ceferin did not want to prejudice this week’s case with charges opened up against the Bulgarians.

It was UEFA doing what they’ve done so often - inadvertently enabling racism to fester across Europe - announcing charges and waiting for the furore to die down before revealing a pitiful punishment a few weeks later on a good day to bury bad news.

In March this year Montenegro were fined just £17,253 for their fans’ well-documented abuse of Gareth Southgate’s England stars.

To put that into perspective, Manchester City were fined more - £24,740 - in 2012 for being just one minute late for a Europa League tie against Sporting Lisbon.

(Image: ITV)

Last year UEFA fined Turkish club Besiktas just under £30,000 for “insufficient organisation” when a cat wandered onto the pitch during their Champions League game with Bayern Munich.

The lack of diversity on UEFA’s Disciplinary committee is also now under scrutiny.

It explains the body’s lack of empathy with the game’s non-white players who are routinely subjected to abuse in England, France, Spain, Italy and eastern Europe.

Of the 10 members of UEFA’s Control, Ethics and Disciplinary Body - which also rules on the women’s game - all are white and all are male.

(Image: Adam Gerrard / Daily Mirror)

Often the body is entitled to rule on instances of racism even if just three of their number are present.

UEFA, which leaves its cases in the hands of lawyers to push, will not be swayed from their dependence on Article 14 of their Disciplinary Regulations.

Although it allow for bans of at least ten matches for racist behaviour from individuals, players insist it does not go far enough for clubs. A string of high-profile stars this week have condemned UEFA’s Three-Step Protocol, dismissing it as unworkable.

In theory it should see players approach the referee after the first instance of abuse with an announcement made to fans to stop.

(Image: Adam Gerrard / Daily Mirror)

After a second instance the match is suspended after a second announcement with the players sent to their dressing rooms for a specific period. After a third instance the match is abandoned.

Again, however, nobody at UEFA could explain why Croatian referee Ivan Bebek, the official on Monday night, did not show any leadership and walk the players off after the second instance.

It was symptomatic of the lack of leadership at UEFA. Now though, the spotlight will stay on them.
description: UEFA say little beyond soundbites and at their plush Swiss HQ no one has any answers when questioned about their pitiful record in combating racism
